qas.question: Early consensus was that London's name originated in what language?
What is the meaning of the later-believed pre-Celtic Old European origin of London's name?
What is the modern Welsh form o the word London?
Who came up with an explanation of the origins of London's name that contradicted earlier assumptions
In what year did Richard Coates offer a differing explanation as to the origins of London's name?

context: From 1898, it was commonly accepted that the name was of <a0_0>Celtic<a0_0/> origin and meant place belonging to a man called *Londinos; this explanation has since been rejected. <a3_0>Richard Coates<a3_0/> put forward an explanation in <a4_0>1998<a4_0/> that it is derived from the pre-Celtic Old European *(p)lowonida, meaning <a1_0>'river too wide to ford<a1_0/>', and suggested that this was a name given to the part of the River Thames which flows through London; from this, the settlement gained the Celtic form of its name, *Lowonidonjon; this requires quite a serious amendment however. The ultimate difficulty lies in reconciling the Latin form Londinium with the modern Welsh <a2_0>Llundain<a2_0/>, which should demand a form *(h)lōndinion (as opposed to *londīnion), from earlier *loundiniom. The possibility cannot be ruled out that the Welsh name was borrowed back in from English at a later date, and thus cannot be used as a basis from which to reconstruct the original name.
